Award.AwardTitle: Polarized Ultra Cold Neutrons for Fundamental Symmetry Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
The universe displays several very fundamental symmetries with major consequences. Three of these are very familiar: that the origin in space of an experiment doesn't matter gives rise to momentum conservation; that the orientation in space doesn't matter gives rise to angular momentum conservation; that the time you start an experiment doesn't matter gives rise to energy conservation. These are known as 'continuous' symmetries.

Less familiar are the 'discrete' symmetries. The most familiar ones are: (P) looking at the universe through a mirror; (C) changing all matter to anti-matter (and vice-versa); and (T) running the clock backwards. These are known to not be 'exact', but the combination of all three 'CPT' is at the foundation of all our theories. That the combination of 'CP' is violated is necessary to explain the origin of the small asymmetry which gives rise to our matter dominated universe.

The cleanest way to study such fundamental symmetries is with simple well-understood systems. The neutron is a prime example. By measuring correlations in its beta decay properties we can probe fine details of its symmetry violation as well as several other important physics questions.

Using ultra-cold neutrons makes these measurements very clean, and this grant supports one of the technologies required to make such experiments possible: the transport of ultra-cold neutrons from their production area to the experimental area and subsequent storage. Specialized coatings are required for this, and both evaporation (such as Ni-58) and laser deposition (of diamond films) have been developed with excellent results.

The program is to improve the capabilities (such as with multi-layer films) and to integrate the technology into fundamental physics studies. These coatings are already being used in the UCN-A experiment at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, and several other groups are interested in using them as well.

The techniques necessary to produce high-quality coatings include precision surface preparation, careful environment control, and comprehensive diagnostics. This provides an excellent training venue for students and new researchers, and couples them directly into critical roles for physics research both from a technology viewpoint, and as part of larger collaborative efforts to probe for new physics.

In addition, these techniques find application in a variety of industrial processes, where successful coatings require very specialized skills and hand-on experience. For example, diamond coatings can significantly prolong the life of quartz process systems, can improve environment resistance of micro strain gauges, and provide harder surfaces for knife-edges. In accelerator systems, coatings play a significant role in ion source efficiencies and the holding time of polarized target cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Polarized Ultra Cold Neutrons for Fundamental Symmetry Study" is one facet of the "UCN-A" collaboration, which has several major acomplishments, the most signficant being the completion and publication of two updates to measurements of the beta asymmetry with the UCNA experiment and the publication of a detailed assessment of the performance of the ultracold neutron source we have constructed at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE), now one of the strongest sources in the world.

The neutron decays into a proton, electron and an antineutrino. The parity-violating angular correlation "A" between the initial neutron spin and the outgoing electron momentum provides the most precise determination of one of the two fundamental coupling constants that determine the strength of the charged weak interaction, called the "axial" coupling constant. This quantity is important for high precision predictions of: the rate at which the sun produces energy; neutrino cross sections; and searches for physics beyond the current standard model of particle physics.

We used "ultracold neutrons" (UCNs), which move at less than about 8 m/s and give us new handles on both polarizing the neutrons and keeping background signals produced by the neutrons as small as possible. What makes UCNs remarkable is the fact that they reflect from many material surfaces, and can be stored in material vessels or magnetic traps for many minutes.  (Deveping these materials for this experiment was the focus of our research grant.)

UCN are guided into our decay vessel, passing through a very strong magnetic polarizing field region, and then enter the decay vessel inside of a magnetic spectrometer. The kinetic energy of the UCN are so low (below about 240 neV in our experiment) that the high field region in the polarizer/AFP magnet creates a potential barrier for one of the two spin states of the neutron due to the interaction of the magnetic moment with the field. The potential energy barrier is about 60 neV/T, so a strong field can reject ALL UCN in the spin-state that is repelled by the magnetic field. This leads to essentially 100 percent poalrized UCN in the high field region.

After the neutron passes through this region, the almost perfect polarization slowly degrades due to various processes in the guide system, so we must measure the polarization to extract a high precision value for the beta asymmetry, but we find the polarization stays about 99 percent, even after the UCN have been stored in our decay volume for more than 20 s. Because UCNs move slowly, they have a relatvely high chance of decaying in our spectrometer compared to the traditional beams experiments, making the neutron-produced backgrounds easier to control as well, since far fewer neutrons need to be sent through the system to get the same decay signal.

When a neutron decays in the measurement spectrometer, the emitted electrons are captured in a 1 T magnetic field and spiral to detectors situated parallel and antiparallel to the field. The difference in the rates in these detectors is proportional to the beta asymmetry. Because the beta-asymmetry changes sign when you flip the neutron spin, we actually measure the ratio in each detector of the rates with the neutron spin parallel and antiparallel to the spectrometer magnetic field. This has the advantage of almost eliminating dependence on the detector efficiencies.

We reported on two high precision measurements of the asymmetry, with the second just below the percent level.
